title: 104_s770
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Jerusalem Embassy Relocation Implementation Act of 1995". The Congress finds that Jerusalem has been the capital of Israel since 1950, serving as the seat of government and a spiritual center for Judaism. The city was divided from 1948-1967 but was reunited during the Six Day War. Since 1967, Jerusalem has been a united city administered by Israel, guaranteeing full access to holy sites for all faiths. The US Congress commemorated the 25th anniversary of Jerusalem's reunification in 1992, reaffirming its stance on the city's undivided status. The Declaration of Principles in 1993 outlined a timetable for interim self-government arrangements. The Interim Self-Government Arrangements set a timetable for resolving final status issues, including Jerusalem. The Agreement on the Gaza Strip and Jericho Area was signed in 1994, starting a five-year transitional period. In 1995, 93 US Senators urged the relocation of the US Embassy to Jerusalem. The US recognizes Jerusalem as Israel's capital and conducts official business there. In 1996, Israel will celebrate the 3,000th anniversary of Jewish presence in Jerusalem, solidifying its status as the capital. SEC. 3. TIMETABLE. The policy states that Jerusalem should be recognized as the capital of Israel, the groundbreaking for the US Embassy in Jerusalem should start by December 31, 1996, and the embassy should be officially open by May 31, 1999. Funding for construction and opening of the embassy is subject to specific conditions. The funds allocated for the Department of State in 1999 for building maintenance abroad can only be used once the US Embassy in Jerusalem officially opens, as determined by the Secretary of State reporting to Congress. SEC. 4. FISCAL YEAR 1995 FUNDING. $5,000,000 allocated for relocating the US Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem. Funds available for site identification, surveys, and land acquisition. Governed by State Department Basic Authorities Act.

SEC. 5. FISCAL YEARS 1996 AND 1997 FUNDING. In fiscal years 1996 and 1997, funds are allocated for the relocation of the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem. $25,000,000 is designated for fiscal year 1996, and $75,000,000 for fiscal year 1997. Additionally, a report on the implementation of the relocation is required. The Secretary of State must submit a report within 30 days of the Act's enactment detailing the plan for relocating the US Embassy to Jerusalem, including estimated completion dates and funding requirements. Additionally, seminannual reports are required. Beginning January 1, 1996, the Secretary of State must report every six months to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate on the progress towards opening the United States Embassy in Jerusalem. The term "United States Embassy" refers to the offices of the diplomatic mission and the residence of the chief of mission.
